intro: Gundlachia truncata, commonly known as the narrowleaf gundlachia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, often hairy stems and small, compound leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Gundlachia truncata typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments, making it a hardy species in desert regions. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
